text.primary: Light's changing.
Feels like it might rain.
Same as yesterday, more or less.

interactions.notes: Once-per-day variation to avoid repetition spam.

text.primary: If you want the chair, it's free.

interactions.notes: Choice handling lives in game logic; this is the offer line only.

text.primary: Tea?
Oh—there you are.
Still here? Good.

interactions.notes: Use sparingly; 'Good' must not read as judgment (tone contract governs).

text.primary: If you pass the hedge, chamomile grows there.
Look for the small flowers that smell like rest.

interactions.notes: Tag-driven hint; no specific ingredient required.

text.primary: Through the hedge, you'll find something gentle.

interactions.notes: Keeps your earlier 'through the hedge' pattern; stays non-directive.

text.primary: If you want something for sleep, pick what smells like quiet.
Stone from the water is fine. Any will do.

interactions.notes: Uses 'any will do' to avoid optimization tone.

text.primary: Some paths keep their own time.
It'll be there.
If a door is quiet, listen first.
Some places open easier when you're not in a hurry.
You can come back to it later. It won't sulk.

interactions.notes: Keeps the tone light; no readiness framing.

text.primary: If you lose track of time, that's normal here.
The animal pauses, listening, as if the air changed.
The animal makes a small circle, then settles.
The animal noses at something half-hidden in the grass.

interactions.notes: Generic animal 'find' behavior; actual spawn handled by system.

text.primary: The animal stops at the edge of the path and waits, unbothered.
The animal stops at a seam in the path, then sits like it's keeping watch.
The animal edges forward, then waits—patient, as if timing matters.
The animal turns in a slow circle at the edge of the path, then chooses to stay.
Morning. Want something warm?
Some ingredients behave better when you don't stare at them.

interactions.notes: Subtle threshold-adjacent line; no readiness framing.

text.primary: I made extra. If you want one, take it.

interactions.notes: Actual item grant handled by game logic (e.g., gift pool) if you want.

text.primary: If you can't find one herb, choose another that smells like ease.
Mint likes the edges—where people walk, but not too often.
Some stones like pockets. Some like windowsills.
If you find a door that isn't there tomorrow, don't argue with it.

interactions.notes: Borderline surreal; ensure tone_contract permits 'door' language.

text.primary: You're dry enough. That's something.
If you want dry kindling, check the shed—back left.

interactions.notes: Only triggers if weather includes 'rain' (string match in your engine).

text.primary: Past the fallen log, the ground flattens out. Good for finding things.
This part always smells different after wind.

interactions.notes: Weather token 'wind' must match your engine.

text.primary: Old places keep quiet rules. Mostly about patience.
If the grass is moving, things are fine.
The path stays kind if you keep to the edges.
You can see the whole day from here.
This is one of those places where the air listens back.
After a rough tide, look where the foam ends.
The boards remember footsteps.
If you stand still, you'll see the small things move.
Water looks different when you don't need anything from it.
Moss threads between your feet, then sits on the stoop like it was always theirs.
Moss pats at a loose thread until it catches the light.

interactions.notes: Pairs well with Moss gift pools.

text.primary: Moss nudges a small button from under the step, then pretends it was nothing.
Moss taps at a ribbon end until it slides into view.
Ink drops a folded scrap beside you and hops back, as if to say: that's all.
Ink lands, drops a bright coin, and tilts their head like it's a joke.
Ink leaves a feather where you can't miss it, then disappears into the branches.
Bram looks back once, then trots toward the waterline at an easy pace.
Bram bumps your hand once, then heads for the gate like he's offering company.
Bram waits until you look up, then starts walking—slow enough to follow or not.
Sable stands at the treeline for a breath, then disappears into green.
Marl pauses beside a flat stone, then waits as if it matters.

interactions.notes: Tortoise as 'slow pointer' to ground items.

text.primary: Vesper shifts in the rafters. A feather drifts down without hurry.
Pip answers the waterfall with a steady croak, as if keeping time.
Luna hops a few paces ahead, then waits with a polite stillness.

interactions.notes: Rabbit as gentle invitation to wander; not a directive.
